â–· The Way I Used To Be By Amber Smith
@ambersmithauthor 

â–· This book really amplifies the saying "one act can change your life" and that's what happened to Eden sadly. The stage's this book goes through is freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior year and seeing how much the traumatic experience changes Eden's life throughout the years of her high school experience. Reading this definitely had moments where it was too hard to read but it was worth it. It was quite a learning experience for me. If you have the time I would recommend giving this book a go for sure!

â–· TW: Rape

#bookstagram #bookstagrammer #booktok #bookreview #thewayiusedtobebook #sadbooks #youngadultbooks #youngadult #books

The Way I Used To Be by @ambersmithauthor . The novel is told in four parts of the main character Edenâ€™s life. Her freshman, sophomore, junior and senior year. One night when Eden is 14, she is sexual assaulted by her brothers best friend. She doesnâ€™t tell anyone about what happened. As she tries to tell her mother the fear from her assaulters threats stops her. So she carries the weight of the trauma alone. As the story evolves, you see how the trauma of the assault and the painful secret effects her relationships, her decisions and self worth. The book is a really hard read especially the chapter on her assault and Edenâ€™s coping mechanisms. 

Eden is so strong, sheâ€™s real and imperfect. She was put simply, trying to cope with what had happened to her. Her experience is her own. I think the novel correctly shows the trauma that a rape leaves behind. Itâ€™s deeply emotional to read, as Eden is tormented by the lasting effects. But it also feels healing, as you see Eden process and work through her pain. 

This book touched my heart, I cried the whole way through. It is so painful to read but you canâ€™t put it down. Itâ€™s a book that has really stuck with me. I felt so angry, sad and devastated reading it. Itâ€™s a moving and powerful novel. 

It is written so well Smith did a wonderful job. Whilst the book breaks my heart, I am so grateful a novel like this exists. It really helps young girls as it shines a light on these horrific experiences and perhaps brings some level of peace to survivors. Edenâ€™s story is one that will always be close to my heart ğŸ’›ğŸ’›. 

I highly recommend this one to everyone itâ€™s truly worth it. ğŸ’›âœ¨ğŸŒ¼ğŸŒ»

5/5 â­ï¸

When I tell you this book was one of the most raw, emotional and powerful books Iâ€™ve ever read, Iâ€™m not lying. Iâ€™m starting this of with the big trigger warning: rape. The title of this book is the perfect way to describe how our main character, Eden goes through life after being raped. She is definitely not the person she used to be. Eden was quite a difficult character for me to understand, but you canâ€™t understand a person if youâ€™ve never experienced what they have. This was one of the first books that every page I turned, I just wanted to scream at her to tell somebody what she went through. But all she did was continuously hurt those she loved so deeply because, well, she was hurting too. Being a stand alone book, the character development is AMAZING. I truly felt like I learned a lot about how certain life altering moments can affect people.

The way I used to be- Amber Smith
â˜… â˜… â˜… â˜…
â€œ And Iâ€™m trying so hard to just go back to my life. The way it used to be. The way I used to be.â€ 

CHECK TW! 
I think everyone has to read this book ones in there life. Itâ€™s such a meaningful story with unfortunately a common topic. It was an eye opener for me. Love every single one of youğŸ«¶ğŸ» 

Story
Eden was always good at being good. Starting high school didn't change who she was. But the night her brother's best friend rapes her, Eden's world capsizes. What was once simple, is now complex. What Eden once loved-who she once loved-she now hates. What she thought she knew to be true, is now lies. Nothing makes sense anymore, and she knows she's supposed to tell someone what happened but she can't. So she buries it instead. And she buries the way she used to be. Told in four parts -freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior year-this provocative debut reveals the deep cuts of trauma. But it also demonstrates one young woman's strength as she navigates the disappointment and unbearable pains of adolescence, of first love and first heartbreak, of friendships broken and rebuilt, and while learning to embrace a power of survival she never knew she had hidden within her heart.

â€œBe like a dandelion. Whenever they fall apart, they start again. Have hope.â€Â  

this book captured my heart and pull me in the entire story. showed me a visual into a world of someone who got hurt, had lost hope, suffered through hardships only to find strength and faith to heal and grow again. this is a story of a young woman to find her strength in the aftermath of an assault. 

i cried, reading about her. she went through deep cuts after cuts. â€œa single act can change your life foreverâ€, they said. in Edenâ€™s story, in the course of 5 minutes in her life, that she was assaulted, sent her into a spiral of despair. times when she doesnâ€™t recognised herself. 

â€œWhatever he thinks that I am, I'm not. And whatever he thinks my body is, it isn't. My body is a torture chamber. It's a f***ing crime scene.â€

this book, puts you into the instant involvement of Eden's emotions; her pain, her shame and fear,  as well as the feeling that sheâ€™s been damaged beyond repair. times when she thinks sheâ€™s unlikely to ever be treated with respect and tenderness. 

*The author's resource note at the end and include the free hotline for the Rape, Abuse, & Incest National Network: 1-800-656-HOPE. If you need someone, please know help is available and confidential.

"i dont know who i am right now. but i know who im not. and i like that" - the way i used to be by amber smith

Book title: The Way I Used To Be
Author: Amber Smith

Trigger Warnings: this book does have discussions and depictions of rape as well as suicidal ideation.

This book was so beautiful and got me so mad and frustrated. It truly shows how across years how trauma can effect so many aspects of a persons life for years. I read this book in two sittings, and I was in awe.

Synopsis: Eden was always good at being good. Starting high school didnâ€™t change who she was. But the night her brotherâ€™s best friend rapes her, Edenâ€™s world capsizes.

What was once simple, is now complex. What Eden once lovedâ€”who she once lovedâ€”she now hates. What she thought she knew to be true, is now lies. Nothing makes sense anymore, and she knows sheâ€™s supposed to tell someone what happened but she canâ€™t. So she buries it instead. And she buries the way she used to be.

Told in four partsâ€”freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior yearâ€”this provocative debut reveals the deep cuts of trauma. But it also demonstrates one young womanâ€™s strength as she navigates the disappointment and unbearable pains of adolescence, of first love and first heartbreak, of friendships broken and rebuilt, all while learning to embrace the power of survival she never knew she had hidden within her heart.

#thewayiusedtobe #thewayiusedtobebook #ambersmith #emotionalbook #mentalhealthawareness #metoo

â‹†Â·Ëš à¼˜ *the way i used to be by amber smith â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† 4.75/5
the review and the slides contains spoilers !!!

first of all pls notice that this book contains a lot of triggers and the characters are all a bit toxic and with younger readers reading this book, this can have a very bad influence on them. ages 12+ should read this book, not any younger than that. also please before reading check the trigger warnings list first
this book discusses: sex*al ass*ult/ suicidal thoughts/ a lot of alc*hol consumption/ dr*gs/ underage s*x

now getting into the actual review. this book talks about eden who gets r*ped by her brother's bestfriend at the age of 13, doesn't tell anyone about it not even her family and how her journey is like after that traumatic experience. 
what I found is that this book is highly realistic. it shows how a single worst thing could just completely turn the tide of your whole life, it brings out something feral that you'd never imagined to be...
i really above all like the way how the author reinforced the fact that you yourself are the only person who could pick up your shattered pieces and mend it and that there are limitations for others.. throughout the whole book people try to help eden but they fail because as long as you don't open yourself to healing, people won't know how to support you and it might even drive them away. you have to let yourself grieve, break then mend and heal so you can accept the help offered to you.
i enjoyed reading all the parts of the book; they were all unique in their own way and how different eden's actors were in every part as she grew and as the emotions kept bottling up til the point of a breakdown, it gave me a new perspective and the self-sabotage was beautifully written.
as for the ending, I really wanted to see what happens with her friends but i can understand why it wasn't added. i think the author wanted to focus more on eden by the end instead of giving us the reactions and i respect that but i just felt like it was kind of rushed? like i expected bit more but i can see why some people love it. it was a the ending that leaves us with questions but content and hopeful.

TW: Rape, Sexual assault and harassment, substance abuse, bullying

Another tough read which is all I seem to be reading lately lol. I actually finished this book about a week ago but got caught up reading other stuff that I forgot to review it. â€œThe Way I Used to Beâ€ tells the story of Eden and her journey to put herself back together after being raped by a close family friend. The book is told in 4 parts, detailing her freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior years of high school. At its heart, itâ€™s a story about how one event can change your entire life, and how hard it can be to pick up the pieces and move forward. 

I had a really good time reading this book, it definitely dealt with tough subject matter and had me crying on more than one occasion. Eden is a very relatable and likable protagonist who you can definitely relate to in a lot of ways. While some of the book feels a bit rushed, I definitely would still recommend it to anyone. 4.5/5â­ï¸

The Way I Used To Be by Amber Smith 
â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸.5 / 5 
- TRIGGER WARNING - SA, Bullying, Substance Abuse.
This book is definitely very underrated. I read this book a few years ago and reread it very recently. Eden, is such a misunderstood character who only needed someone to truly see her. I was extremely bummed out by the ending but I understood that Eden needed to become her own savior and find herself again and fully heal. 
This book definitely means a lot to me <3

the way i used to be - amber smith 

CW - rape (graphic), substance abuse
ğŸ–¤ğŸ–¤ğŸ–¤

â€œthe plan was to get better, to feel better, by any means. but i donâ€™t feel better, i feel empty, empty and broken, stillâ€
-

the way i used to be is told over the course of four years, following the night that eden was raped by her brotherâ€™s best friend. we see edenâ€™s development through these years as she navigates through life, trying to get as far away from the girl she used to be as possible. this book explores trauma in an emotional and very real way.

while being focused solely on eden and her development throughout the years, this book isnâ€™t very plot-driven, yet is still able to be engaging and spark really important discussions. 

eden is a very real, human character. we see her acting self-destructive, hurting those she loves, and putting herself in dangerous situations as her perception of the world changes. we also begin to see her take responsibility and begin the path of healing, which was an emotional end to the novel.

overall, this book was an important read and it was very well done, however due to its contents it was a little hard to read. i gave it 3/5 stars.

This book hurt so bad. I had to stop multiple times & I cried ):

Talking about sexual assault is hard but extremely important. 

Despite being painful to read, and extremely triggering, seeing the effects of trauma unfold so intimately in a characters life just goes to illustrate how important seeking help is, and the effects of not.

Definitely recommend!

Hmmm. I really donâ€™t know how to write the review of this book because itâ€™s one of those books that you just want to finish so youâ€™d move on to another bookğŸ˜… 
â€˜The Way I Used To Beâ€™ is a book about s*xual assault.

The main characters is Eden McCrorey, Edy for short. She was a victim of rape when she was about twelve years old, by her brother's best friend, Kevin Armstrong.
She goes through high school believing she couldnâ€™t confide in anyone about what had happened to her, which made her do a lot of unreasonable things that really got me pissed.
Though this book made me understand the trauma of those who had gone through the same, but Iâ€™d like to say that we shouldnâ€™t allow our past rule our present. Your past can either make you or mar you, so choose which.

I only enjoyed reading the beginning and the end parts of the book. All through the middle, the only thing I felt was rage.

I will give it a 3â­ï¸
Have you read the book? Iâ€™d like to know your view in the commentsğŸ¥°

The way I used to be written by Amber Smith. 
â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸
This story looks at how trauma can affect your actions. How not talking about that trauma can eat at all of your healthy relationships. Also, how that trauma doesnâ€™t give you an excuse to inflict pain on anyone else. 
A must read story. Check trigger warnings. 
But unfortunately no tearsâ€¦. ğŸ˜¢

ğŸ’™ The Way I Used To Be ğŸ’™

â™¾/5

I knew that when I first decided to read this book that it was going to be a sad one and it was going to break my heart. What I didnâ€™t know was that it would soon become one of my most favourite stand alone books that I have ever read!

Eden, precious Eden!ğŸ¥º what this girl had to experience at such a young age hurt! It really hurt! But the respect and love I had for her throughout the book was insane!

After a horrible event you see the aftermath and how this event affects Edens life throughout freshman, sophomore, junior and senior year. You see how she handles her relationships with her friends, future love interests and her family. You also get to see how she navigates her emotions.

There were many parts throughout the book where I related to Eden and her lack of trust! I understood what she was going through in parts of the book and how certain events can make you feel and act a certain way. This just made me love the book even more!

I feel that when you can relate to a book you just have this extra level of love and connection to itğŸ¥°

I loved Joshâ€™s character and what he brought to the book. I know a lot of people didnâ€™t like the ending but I thought it was fantastic!

You need to realise that Eden needed to find who she was on her own two feet and needed to work through her trauma by herself while having people there for her!

Overall this was a very very good book and I will forever hold it close to my heart! If you choose to read this book please look up the trigger warnings first!

I believe this book was wonderfully writtenğŸ¥°

<3 KC

i first read â€œThe Way I Used to Beâ€ back in April, but last night, i felt the need to re read it. this book is one of the most heartbreakingly beautiful things that iâ€™ve ever read, and itâ€™s so hard for me to put into words how i truly feel about it. it somehow broke my heart open and put it back together every chapter, and iâ€™m so so happy i decided fo pick up this book when i did. i just wanted to hug Eden so tightly, and for so much of the book, i felt like i was walking that journey with her â€” which is exactly what i needed. This was such an easy read but it took me more than I planned to finish reading. It was because I knew I was going to get heartbroken and I was procrastinating. So today, solely for this reason I took my book with me and went to a coffee shop, sat at a table that was directly under the sun and I finished this book. Honestly I think it was not the best decision to read the last part of the book in public because I tried very hard to hold my tears. 
â€¢
Reading this book was a different experience. It proves to you how one messed up person can cause a chain reaction and ruin bunch of peopleâ€™s lives. I felt so much and I think that is because the author expressed feelings so genuinely. At times I was frustrated with the heroine and at times I was frustrated with other characters in the book. And during this the author never gave me a chance to be angry with a character more than a few pages. Her writing gives you so much insight on how all of the characters feel and you find yourself empathising even with the characters you donâ€™t want to empathise. Except the antihero of this book. In the book his reasoning for being this way is briefly mentioned but never in detail. I canâ€™t empathise with him. I. Will. Not.
â€¢
CW: this book talks about sexual assault in detail and focuses on Heroineâ€™s inner struggles/ feelings after she was sexually assaulted. 
â€¢
The things this book thought me and made me remember:

Reach out to people. Talk to professionals. And when you are strong enough, talk about it so others can learn from you and maybe also find the courage to speak up. 

Especially tell the ones who want to ignore your struggles. Make them uncomfortable. Donâ€™t let them act like everything is okay. Particularly, if you are form a culture in which people advise you to take bunch of precautions, who ask you why you were wearing what you were wearing and why were you out so late. Donâ€™t. Let. Them. 

And lastly if you are a parent, always remind your kids that you are their safe space. That there is nothing in this world that would diminish your love for them. I was a lucky kid and I still am because there wasnâ€™t one moment I felt like my mother wasnâ€™t on my side.
